meta_data.title: Geometric Tree Representation Learning via Geometric Tree Message Passing and Self-supervised Learning
meta_data.abstract: Geometric trees are prevalent complex data structures, found in diverse domains such as neuron morphology and river networks. Their intricate hierarchical, geometric, and topological relationships necessitate advanced representation learning techniques that can capture these properties. This research presents a novel approach called Geometric Tree Message Passing (GTMP) and complements it with a self-supervised learning framework, namely Geometric Tree Self-Supervised Learning (GT-SSL), to effectively learn geometric tree representations.

relate work.comparisons with related methods: Existing methods like Tree-LSTM focus on hierarchical structures but lack explicit design for geometric and spatial attributes. GTMP bridges this gap by incorporating geometric information in its representation learning approach.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper introduces a novel approach for geometric tree representation learning, which effectively captures the geometric, hierarchical, and topological attributes inherent in tree-structured data.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To develop a representation learning method for geometric trees that accurately preserves their spatial, topological, and hierarchical properties.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Existing methods struggle with integrating geometric and hierarchical information, which is vital for accurately modeling complex geometric trees.
high_level_summary.method summary: The proposed GTMP model and the GT-SSL learning framework leverage message passing in tree branches and self-supervised objectives tailored for geometric trees, respectively.
high_level_summary.conclusion: The integration of GTMP with GT-SSL creates a powerful method for learning comprehensive geometric tree representations, significantly outperforming existing frameworks.

Method.description: The proposed GTMP model employs a message passing mechanism focusing on tree branches to preserve the overall geometric structure of the trees. GT-SSL, the associated self-supervised framework, enhances the modelâ€™s capabilities by leveraging unsupervised tasks tailored for geometric trees.
Method.problem formultaion: How to effectively learn the representation of a geometric tree that combines spatial, hierarchical, and topological attributes?
Method.model: GTMP uses branch message passing neural networks which are integrated with partial ordering and subtree growth learning for self-supervised tasks.
Method.theoretical analysis: Theoretical guarantees are given for the invariance of representations against rotation and translation, ensuring the robustness of the learned representations.
Method.complexity: Our approach demonstrates linear time complexity relative to the number of nodes, offering scalability over large datasets.

Experiments.setup: The evaluation contained both supervised and self-supervised contexts, leveraging eight real-world datasets.
Experiments.results: The GTMP model, especially when paired with the GT-SSL framework, consistently outperforms baseline methods with a margin of 15.6%+ in AUC scores on average.
Experiments.performance: The combined approach excels in representing and leveraging geometric tree structures effectively, offering robustness in real-world applications.
Experiments.analysis: Presence of strong self-supervised learning that significantly enhances the tree representation learning capabilities beyond traditional supervised methods.
Experiments.ablation study: Key components, including branch message passing and partial ordering, were validated for their impact on representation quality.

conclusion.summary: The research introduces a powerful method for geometric tree representation learning, leveraging both structured design and self-supervised learning, with significant improvements in performance.
conclusion.future work: Exploring transferability in unseen domains and potential application in biological data analysis, enhancing interpretability features.
